title: Negative Prefixes
description: Negative prefixes are added to the beginning of a word to change its meaning to the opposite. This is a common way to form antonyms in English.

tips.title: Common Negative Prefixes
tips.description: Here's a list of the most common negative prefixes in English:

tips.title: Prefix Rules
tips.description: While there are some general patterns, it's important to note that the choice of prefix often depends on the specific word. However, here are some tendencies:
examples: - **im-** is often used before words beginning with **m** or **p**.
- **il-** is often used before words beginning with **l**.
- **ir-** is often used before words beginning with **r**.

tips.title: Formation of Antonyms
tips.description: Negative prefixes are a key tool for expanding vocabulary by creating antonyms.  Understanding them helps in recognizing and understanding new words.
examples: The prefix **un-** is very common and can be added to many adjectives.
Adding **in-** can change the meaning of some adjectives and nouns.
**Dis-** often negates verbs, and some nouns and adjectives.

tips.title: Important Note
tips.description: Not all words can take a negative prefix. Sometimes, different words are used to express the opposite meaning (e.g., 'good' and 'bad', not 'ungood').
